who is uncle Tom ? >>>>> Uncle Tom is a pejorative term for a black person who is perceived by other blacks to be obsequiously servile to white authority figures , or who simply are perceived as being unnecessarily accommodating of whites . The term Uncle Tom comes from the title character of white author Harriet Beecher Stowe 's novel Uncle Tom 's Cabin . [[It_1]] is used to denote African Americans whose political views or allegiances are labeled by critics as detrimental to black Americans as a group . This term has been used by some African - Americans to malign black Republicans and appointees , due to their participation in a Republican administration , although [[it_2]] has also been used to describe Democratic African - American politicians accused of ignoring the African - American community .

what 's google 's marketing concept ? >>>>> There are basically two products by Google . One is Adwords and the other is Adsense . Adwords is a technology that helps the advertiser place his advertisements on webpages that allow Google Ads to be placed . The advertiser sets a minimum cost per click that he is ready to pay when someone clicks on his ad . Now , the ads are ranked according to the relevancy and the cost per click . There 's another way of placing the ad . [[It_1]] is called cost per 1000 impressions . You can read more on Adwords at : http://adwords. google . com Adsense : Adsense is a technology by Google that allows a website owner to place Ads on his webpages . You can even have Adsense on your blogs . The idea is , allow Google Ads on your website and when someone clicks on the ad , you get revenue . You can find more on Adsense at : http://adsense. google . com

Why do credit cards have an expiration date ? >>>>> The magnetic stripe wears out over time ; [[it_1]] 's easier to manage getting new ones to people if they just automatically send them to everyone when they get close to their estimated end of life cycle than to wait for customers to call in saying their card stopped working . People would be pretty annoyed if all of a sudden their card was no good and they could n't figure out why ! This also helps " phase - in " new technologies in that stripe , like how some gas stations now ask for your zip code when you buy gas . This helps verify your identity but a credit card issued 20 years ago will not " know " how to " talk " to the bank when [[it_2]] is read by the gas pump . So retiring old cards and shipping out new ones allows companies to update what that stripe " knows " how to do .

Why do some people never learn morality ? >>>>> Being moral and being immoral are both survival srategies . A simple way to think about [[it_1]] is to consider " cheaters " and " cooperators " . In a world of all cooperators , a cheater will do very well because he 'll be trusted . In a world of all cheaters , those who can cooperate will do very well because nobody else can work together . So the extremes of all cooperators or all cheaters are not evolutionary stable strategies . Because in general , cooperation works better than cheating , the people of the world are generally moral cooperators . But the real world is a stable balance of cooperation , competition , honest , dishonesty , etc. In this environment the totally immoral selfish person can do quite well , so a generally good society is always saddled with a certain number of sociopaths . The most direct answer to why some do n't learn [[it_2]] is , some are not capable of learning [[it_3]] . I 've attempted a simple explanation of why we are stuck with people like that .

Sometimes , a letter of intent may also be issued by a mutual fund shareholder to indicate that he / she would like to invest certain amounts of money at certain specified times . Is $ 75,000 . 00 a year income a good income ? OR . . . . should I opt for $ 35 . 00 an hour instead ? >>>>> Depends , are you going to work more than an hour of overtime a week ? If so , you 'll get more money if you go with the hourly , otherwise , working 40 hour weeks , 75K / yr will gross you about 2K more . A yearly salary is wonderful , especially for budgeting purposes . [[It_1]] is n't affected by sick leave or vacation time , and you are n't going to lose out on money just because you are n't there . Personally , because I do n't get sick often , I like my work , and I like the idea of putting in an extra hour when I need to so I can make an extra buck , I 'd go with the hourly . But if the whole guaranteed check makes you happy , do [[it_2]] instead .

how is a dual core processor different ? >>>>> A dual core processor is exactly what [[it_1]] sounds like . This does not mean that the chip itself is faster . [[It_3]] means that the capability exists via the HyperTransport pathway for one chip to “ talk ” to another chip or device at a faster speed and with greater data throughput . What s a blog ? >>>>> A blog is a personal diary . A daily pulpit . A collaborative space . A political soapbox . A breaking - news outlet . A collection of links . Your own private thoughts . Memos to the world . Your blog is whatever you want [[it_1]] to be . There are millions of them , in all shapes and sizes , and there are no real rules . In simple terms , a blog is a web site , where you write stuff on an ongoing basis . New stuff shows up at the top , so your visitors can read what 's new . Then they comment on [[it_2]] or link to [[it_3]] or email you . Or not . Since Blogger was launched , almost five years ago , blogs have reshaped the web , impacted politics , shaken up journalism , and enabled millions of people to have a voice and connect with others . And we 're pretty sure the whole deal is just getting started .

I am trying to find the advantages and challenges of a team using Access to create a database . . ? I also need to know about the pros and cons . >>>>> Challenges 1. Getting the team to agree on application design requirements . 2. Designing the tables to support those requirements . 3. Maintaining data integrity as you add / change / delete records through your application . 4. Maintaining performance once you get to about 6 concurrent users . If your team is larger that that , consider SQL Server as a back end and just use Access as the front end interface . Advantages 1. Forces you to plan and rationalize your data requirements . 2. Good reporting tools . 3. Helps make the data more consistant . No assurance , but [[it_1]] helps . Suggestion : Start with the reports you will need . That will help assure that you include all the inputs needed to get what you need . Seems backwards , but [[it_2]] works better to start with what you need as output and then figure out what inputs produce that output . Have done a few applications in Access and this technique seems to work fairly well . Best of luck .

What is open source software and how do I benefit from [[it_1]] ? >>>>> Open source describes practices in production and development that promote access to the end product 's source materials — typically , their source code . Some consider [[it_2]] as a philosophy , and others consider [[it_3]] as a pragmatic methodology . Before open source became widely adopted , developers and producers used a variety of phrases to describe the concept ; the term open source gained popularity with the rise of the Internet and [[it_4]] s enabling of diverse production models , communication paths , and interactive communities . [ 1 ] Subsequently , open source software became the most prominent face of open source practices . The open source model can allow for the concurrent use of different agendas and approaches in production , in contrast with more centralized models of development such as those typically used in commercial software companies . [ 2 ] " Open source " as applied to culture defines a culture in which fixations are made generally available . Participants in such a culture are able to modify those products and redistribute them back into the community . More on http://en. wikipedia . org / wiki / Open_source

how to become a good teacher ? please give me some advices >>>>> Always listen . Always observe carefully . Let their minds be free . On a dollar bill . . . . . . . . . . . . . ? What does a pyramid and an eye have to do with the bill ? >>>>> The reverse of the one dollar bill has an ornate design that incorporates the Great Seal of the United States , and [[it_1]] is of noted interest to historians and numerologists for the symbols contained therein . To the left is the reverse of the seal which portrays an unfinished pyramid . The separated cap of the pyramid , portraying the all - seeing eye , symbolizes that the United States is still far from finished . The Latin phrase Annuit Cœptis ( He [ God ] has favored our undertaking ) is located above the pyramid . NOVUS ORDO SECLORUM ( New Order of the Ages ) is shown on a ribbon below the pyramid . Written at the base of the pyramid in Roman Numerals is MDCCLXXVI or 1776 , the year the United States Declaration of Independence was signed .

who is d father of microbiology . ? >>>>> As per literatures , different scientists were claimed as " Father of microbiology " [[It_1]] was in 1665 that Robert Hook published the first book on this subject with the title ' Micrographia ' and he is known as the father of microbiology . Antony ( October 24 , 1632 - August 30 , 1723 ) , full name Thonius Philips van Leeuwenhoek was a Dutch tradesman and scientist from Delft , Netherlands . He is commonly known as " the Father of Microbiology " . Born the son of a basket maker , at age 16 he secured an apprenticeship with a Scottish cloth merchant in Amsterdam . He is best known for his work on the improvement of the microscope and for his contributions towards the establishment of microbiology . Louis Pasteur ( December 27 , 1822 – September 28 , 1895 ) was a French microbiologist and chemist . He is best known for demonstrating how to prevent milk and wine from going sour , which came to be called pasteurization . He is the founder of microbiological sciences and immunology . What is the shape of force versus time graph for an object in linear motion ? I was plotting [[it_1]] but I got force as zero in between some time intervals , just wondering how could force be zero if an object is in motion ? >>>>> If an object is moving at a constant velocity , then the acceleration of that object is zero ( acceleration is the measure of how fast the velocity is changing , if the velocity is unchanging , acceleration must be zero ) . By Newton 's Second Law , if the acceleration of an object is zero , the net force on that object must also be zero . Newton 's First Law also mentions this concept . Once an object is in motion [[it_2]] 'll keep moving at the same velocity forever unless a force acts on that object . Now there must be some force acting on the object initially to get [[it_3]] moving , but once [[it_4]] 's moving you can cut off all the forces on the object and [[it_5]] 'll go forever ( not really a practical experiment though since there are always forces like friction and gravity that cause the motion to stop ) .

is a window a viscous fluid ? >>>>> The answer to that is " no . " The old " glass is a slow moving liquid " bit is an old wives tale . Or in this case , an old professors tale . The essential reason is that in a fluid all the molecules are disordered and only loosely bound . While in glass the molecues are strongly bound , although disordered . There is some wiggle room in the definition of solid and liquid , but [[it_1]] probably does n't matter in this instance . The main evidence for glass being a liquid is the claim that glass in , say , old buildings has slowly settled and made the bottom thinker has never been shown to be due to glass being a liquid . In fact , the existence of perfectly fine glass from the time of the Roman Empire makes [[it_2]] unlikely . The second link I 've included is an extensive discussion of the whole " windows are flowing down " bit - the conclusion being , that [[it_3]] is more likely the panes were made with uneven thickness and the glass was inserted with the thicker end down - which is the logical thing to do in that circumstance .

Why do zippers say YKK on them ? >>>>> [[It_1]] s the name of the company that makes the zippers . From the clothing you wear , the furniture you own , the car you drive , the luggage you carry , and the sports equipment you use , and more , YKK zippers are there . In 1960 , YKK first entered the United States zipper market as a small sales and assembly operation . Originating in New York 's garment district to be near our customers , YKK ( U. S. A. ) Inc. is now this country 's number one supplier of zippers . In Macon , Georgia , in state - of - the - art plants we produce millions of YKK zippers per day in thousands of styles and colors . Does [[it_2]] really take so many plants to make a zipper ? Yes , if [[it_3]] 's a YKK zipper . Our unique manufacturing process is vertically integrated . Starting with the Brass Wire Plant , where our own brass is produced from high grade copper and zinc in a ratio perfect for zippers , we make zipper teeth ( elements ) and sliders . What is the Hollies song , " He a'int heavy , he 's my brother " about ? >>>>> The title came from the motto for Boys Town , a community formed in 1917 by a Catholic priest named Father Edward Flanagan . Located in Omaha , Nebraska , [[it_1]] was a place where troubled or homeless boys could come for help . In 1941 , Father Flanagan was looking at a magazine called The Messenger when he came across a drawing of a boy carrying a younger boy on his back , with the caption , " He ai n't heavy Mr. , he 's my brother . " Father Flanagan thought the image and phrase captured the spirit of Boys Town , so he got permission and commissioned a statue of the drawing with the inscription , " He ai n't heavy Father , he 's my brother . " The statue and phrase became the logo for Boys Town .

What are the criteria for getting a hollywood walk of fame star ? More specifically , is [[it_1]] true that Ryan Seacrest paid to get one . . . and if so . . . how hilarious ! >>>>> Below are the categories for each star . Some celebrities have more than one star in various categories : motion picture camera for contribution to the film industry ; television set for contribution to the broadcast television industry ; phonograph record for contribution to the recording industry ; radio microphone for contribution to the broadcast radio industry ; and , twin comedy / tragedy masks for contribution to live theater . Nominations are submitted annually by May 31 , and the Walk of Fame committee meets the following month to pick the next year 's group of honorees . Star ceremonies are open to the public and are led by Johnny Grant , Hollywood 's Honorary Mayor . In order for a person to get a star on the Walk of Fame , he or she must agree to attend a presentation ceremony within five years of selection , and a $ 15,000 fee must be paid to the Trust for costs such as security at the star ceremony . Is [[it_1]] true that if you get hit in the head you 'd lose brain cells ? >>>>> You lose brain cells every day without anything happening at all . Various things such as smoking , drinking alcohol or taking drugs , OR being hit in the head hard enough to sustain a concussion , will accelerate brain cell loss . But just like with the rest of your body , you also grow new brain cells every day . Therefore , if you get hit in the head and are experiencing some thinking problems -- lack of memory , concentration , etc. -- you will PROBABLY get back most or all of your brain function as long as you do n't do anything to aggravate the situation . Thinking problems related to getting hit in the head are more likely caused by pressure from bruising or swelling against the brain , and not actual " loss " of brain cells .

Alot of people get short of breath , nauseous , sweaty . Some people have every single one of these symptoms , some have only one or two . Women are more likely than men to have atypical symptoms , i. e. , maybe they 're a little nauseous , or their back hurts or their arm feels funny , making [[it_3]] difficult for them to realize [[it_4]] is a cardiac problem and they need to call 911 . . . . what s the average life span of someone with diabetes ? >>>>> Type I diabetes tends to shorten life span alot worse than Type II diabetes . A whole lot depends on the willingness of the patient , and his / her skill in closely controlling the blood sugar . Character plays an important part , as someone who is lazy or likes to drink too much is n't going to do a very good job controlling their blood sugar . Also , depends on other health factors . If you got bad genes for arteriosclerosis apart from the diabetic factor , then you got more problem . Also , the newer insulins and self check glucometers really help the determined to control their sugars . You know a person is not managing to control [[it_1]] well , and can predict an early demise , if they start to develop neuropathy ( such as numbness on bottom of feet ) , retinal problems , and decreased kidney function . But if they 've had [[it_2]] a number of years , and are not developing any of these problems , then they may live a fairly normal lifespan .

if a person walks on to my yard with out permision and my dog bites them can something happen to my dog ? >>>>> The question is one of negligence . You owe a duty of reasonable care . Working against you might be that you let your dog run loose knowing people often crossed your property and that you knew the dog had bitten other people before . Why are nocturnal bugs attracted to light ? If they like light . . . how come they do not come out during the day ? ( Example -- June Bugs ) >>>>> " When insects fly at night they use light sources such as the moon for navigation . Light from a distant source reaches both eyes with the same intensity . This enables the insect to fly in a straight line with both wings beating at the same rate . If the light is from a closer source such as a candle or lantern , [[it_1]] changes the insect 's perception . The light is perceived stronger in one eye than in the other eye . This causes the wing on one side to move faster . The insect then begins to approach the light in a spiral path , eventually drawing them into the light itself . This attraction to light is a response called Phototaxis .

An alternative natural energy resource based on underground hot water resources . is what ? >>>>> Geothermal energy http://en. wikipedia . org / wiki / Geothermal_energy look at this link Geothermal power is generated by mining the earth 's heat . In areas with high temperature ground water at shallow depths , wells are drilled into natural fractures in basement rock or into permeable sedimentary rocks . Hot water or steam flows up through the wells either by pumping or through boiling ( flashing ) flow . Experiments are in progress to determine if a fourth method , deep wells into " hot dry rocks " , can be economically used to heat water pumped down from the surface . A hot dry rock project in the United Kingdom was abandoned after [[it_1]] was pronounced economically unviable in 1989 . HDR programs are currently being developed in Australia , France , Switzerland and Germany . Magma ( molten rock ) resources offer extremely high - temperature geothermal opportunities , but existing technology does not allow recovery of heat from these resources .

what direction does a toilet spin when flushed . . . ? If you flush the toilet on the equater what direction does the water spin . . if at all ? >>>>> Episodes of the Simpsons and urban legend have [[it_1]] that the spin of flushed water is determined by the hemisphere one is in , presumably because cyclones , hurriances , and other large - scale forces of nature spin in opposite directions in opposite hemispheres . Unfortunately the force that makes hurricanes and cyclones spin in opposite directions ( the Coriolis force ) operates on a very large scale , over thousands of miles in fact . The forces that determine whether the toilet flushes clockwise or counter-clockwise are a function of the toilet , no more , no less . The Coriolis force does not operate on such small scales as the whole manifestation of [[it_2]] s effect is seen due to the difference in rotation between two points on Earth that are far apart . So the answer to your question is " Depends on the toilet " , nothing else .

in biochemistry why sucrose does not react with benedicts solution until treated with acid ? i did a test in food . i added sucrose with benedicts solution and put [[it_1]] in hot water for 10 min , i then took [[it_2]] out of the water and cooled [[it_3]] down , [[it_4]] had not changed colour until i treated [[it_5]] with acid and [[it_6]] became an orange colour after another 10 min in the water >>>>> Sucrose is a double sugar ( disaccharide ) of glucose and fructose . Glucose is a reducing sugar ( reacts with Benedict 's , Fehling 's , and Tollen 's solutions ) , because of the oxidation of [[it_7]] 's aldehyde ( - CH = O ) group . Fructose is a reducing sugar because of the oxidation of [[it_8]] s keto ( greater thanC = O ) group . In sucrose , the glucose is bound through [[it_9]] s aldehyde group to the keto group of fructose . Therefore , sucrose is a nonreducing sugar , because the two groups are masked . Treatment with acid hydrolyzes sucrose to glucose and fructose , and the sugar mixture reduces Benedict 's solution .

What is biotechnology ? I am joining XI class with Zoology , PhysicsandChemistry as main subjets . Biotechnology could be an optonal subject for me . So , I want to know what is boitechnolgy1 >>>>> Biotechnology is a technology based on biology , especially when used in agriculture , food science , and medicine . Biotechnology can also be defined as the manipulation of organisms to do practical things and to provide useful products . One section of biotechnology is the directed use of organisms for the manufacture of products . There are also applications of biotechnology that do not use living organisms . Modern biotechnology is often associated with the use of genetically altered microorganisms such as E. coli or yeast for the production of substances like insulin or antibiotics . [[It_1]] can also refer to transgenic animals or transgenic plants , such as Bt corn . Genetically altered mammalian cells , such as Chinese Hamster Ovarian ( CHO ) cells , are also widely used to manufacture pharmaceuticals . Another promising new biotechnology application is the development of plant - made pharmaceuticals . Biotechnology is also commonly associated with breakthroughs in new medical therapies and diagnostic devices .

How would your kidneys maintain the water and mineral balance of your blood on . . . ? a ) a cool day when you stayed inside and drank lots of tea ? or b ) a hot sports day when you ran three races and had forgotten your water bottle ? please help ! >>>>> The kidneys are always trying to maintain homeostasis - keeping the water to mineral ratio in your blood constant . If you stayed inside and drank lots of tea , you will have a big increase in water in your blood , while the amount of minerals stays the same . Your kidneys would then remove lots of water from your blood and keep the minerals , to return the concentration of minerals back to normal . ( You 'll urinate a lot ) If you used up a lot of your body 's water by sweating and then not replenishing [[it_1]] , the mineral concentration would be much higher . The kidneys will try to return the concentration back to normal by letting out a lot of minerals but not a lot of water ( You wo n't urinate as much , and when you do , [[it_2]] will be very concentrated )

What exactly is Area 51 and why is [[it_1]] such a secret ? [[It_2]] seems to be the topic of some rather intersting Science Fiction series . >>>>> Area 51 , also known as Groom Lake , is a secret military facility about 90 miles north of Las Vegas . The number refers to a 6 - by-10 - mile block of land , at the center of which is a large air base the government will not discuss . The site was selected in the mid-1950s for testing of the U-2 spyplane , due to [[it_3]] s remoteness , proximity to existing facilities and presence of a dry lake bed for landings . Groom Lake is America 's traditional testing ground for " black budget " aircraft before they are publicly acknowledged . The facility and surrounding areas are also associated -- with varying levels of credibility -- with UFO and conspiracy stories . In 1989 , Bob Lazar claimed on a Las Vegas television station that he had worked with alien spacecraft at Papoose Lake , south of Area 51 . Since then , " Area 51 " has become a popular symbol for the alleged U. S. Government UFO cover - up . Hope that was helpful .

how does a snake breathe ?? >>>>> The trachea in reptiles is similar to that of higher vertebrates , with well - developed hyaline rings . However , there is no mucociliary transport mechanism to aid the removal of foreign substances from the respiratory tract . Furthermore , the absence of a diaphragm prevents the animal from coughing . The lungs are similar to the avian - type system with a series of reticulated open - ended sacs and many capillaries in close proximity . The cranial part of the reptile lung is the gaseous exchange portion , while the caudal part functions as an air sac . The latter may act as a reserve of air during periods of apnoea . Alveolar macrophages are present in the reptilian lung , but may display poor bacterial removal if the animal is being kept below [[it_1]] s optimal temperature . In snakes , the right lung is larger than the left , and generally stretches from the heart to the kidney . [[It_2]] may extend even further down to the cloaca in some aquatic snakes . Some snakes have a tracheal lung on the dorsal aspect of the trachea , which enables the snake to breathe when the main lung is compressed by swallowed prey .

What are the main differences of Australian English ( compared to British English and American English ) ? >>>>> Australian English is much closer to the original source , as [[it_1]] has had less time to corrupt , and has had more careful guidance , than has American English . Unlike American English , Australian is quite easy to understand , even by elderly English people . To speak with an Australian accent you have to stare at the sun , allow your face to grimace in pain , and then keep your mouth fixed and unmoving , regardless of whatever vowel enunciation may be demanded of [[it_2]] . Never forget that there is no such thing as an " English Accent " when speaking English , any more than there is a French accent when speaking French . However , there are a vast number of very different accents within Britain : many , many more than exist along the entire breadth of the US . Many of these accents are completely incomprehensible to people outside the region . If you were to compare the native speech of the residents of Newcastle , Glasgow , London , Liverpool , Devon , Suffolk and Cardiff , [[it_3]] would be easy to convince a foreigner that they were in fact all speaking different languages .

is spoof@yahoo . com and spoof@ebay . com correct to contact yahoo and ebay about phishing emails sent ? i received a questionable email and want to forward [[it_1]] to yahoo and ebay , what addresses do i use please ? >>>>> Spoof emails are deceptive emails claiming to be sent by well - known companies in an attempt to commit identity theft . If you have any doubt whether an email is really from eBay : * Forward the message to spoof@ebay . com . * Do not alter the subject line or forward the message as an attachment . If you do this [[it_2]] prevents eBay from investigating [[it_3]] further . eBay investigates every spoof reported . Please note that the automatic response you get from eBay may not address you by name . * Once you have forwarded the email , you can then delete [[it_4]] from your email account . Important : Do not click on any link in the email . The purpose of spoof email is to lead you to a Web site and attempt to collect personal information and commit identity theft or other crimes .
